_When you read this poem, what feeling do you get? What is a color that matches that feeling?_

-   Connect blocks from the toolbox under `when run` to build your program. 
-   Find a background and text **effect** that matches the **mood** of this poem.
-   Change the **colors** of your effects or text. 
-   Click "Run" to animate the poem.

-   Add **colors** or **effects** to match a new **line** in the poem. 
-   Make sure the effect changes when the line you want appears on the screen.

https://studio.code.org/s/poetry-hoc3/le.short_instructions: Authors use imagery to paint a picture in the reader's mind. You can add sprites to illustrate your poem.
https://studio.code.org/s/poetry-hoc3/le.long_instructions:
Authors use **imagery** to paint a picture in the reader's mind using words. Add **sprites** to illustrate the images that come to your mind when you read the poem. 

-   Connect a `make new sprite` block under the `when run` block.
-   Choose a costume for your sprite.

_Extra Challenge:_ Connect a `make new sprite` block to an event to make a new sprite appear when a new character is introduced in the poem.

[blockly block][0]

-   Click the pin [][1] on the location block then choose a new position for your sprite on the screen.
-   Press the "Run" button when your code is finished.

https://studio.code.org/s/poetry-hoc3/le.short_instructions: Sprites can do certain actions or behaviors over and over while the program runs.
https://studio.code.org/s/poetry-hoc3/le.long_instructions:
Sprites can do certain actions or **behaviors** over and over while the program runs.

-   Drag out a `sprite begins` block.
-   Explore different sprite behaviors.
-   Choose a behavior that matches your poem.

_Extra Challenge:_ Connect a `sprite begins` block to an **event** to make a sprite begin a behavior when the mood shifts!
